greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array A(n,k), n>=0, k>=0, read by antidiagonals, where column k is the expansion of Product_{j>=1} (1 - x^j)^k.
comment: A(n,k) number of partitions of n into an even number of distinct parts minus number of partitions of n into an odd number of distinct parts with k types of each part.
link: Index entries for expansions of Product_{k >= 1} (1-x^k)^m
formula: G.f. of column k: Product_{j>=1} (1 - x^j)^k.
Column k is the Euler transform of period 1 sequence [-k, -k, -k, ...].
example: A(3,2) = 2 because we have [2, 1], [2', 1], [2, 1'], [2', 1'] (number of partitions of 3 into an even number of distinct parts with 2 types of each part), [3], [3'] (number of partitions of 3 into an odd number of distinct parts with 2 types of each part) and 4 - 2 = 2.
maple: seq(seq(A(n, d-n), n=0..d), d=0..12);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Jun 21 2018
mathematica: Table[Function[k, SeriesCoefficient[Product[(1 - x^i)^k , {i, Infinity}], {x, 0, n}]][j - n], {j, 0, 12}, {n, 0, j}] // Flatten
Table[Function[k, SeriesCoefficient[QPochhammer[x, x, Infinity]^k, {x, 0, n}]][j - n], {j, 0, 12}, {n, 0, j}] // Flatten
Table[Function[k, SeriesCoefficient[Sum[(-1)^i*x^(i*(3*i + 1)/2), {i, -Infinity, Infinity}]^k, {x, 0, n}]][j - n], {j, 0, 12}, {n, 0, j}] // Flatten
results.author: _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, May 08 2017
